title: Congress stays in the slow lane on auto safety
content:
Not even 64 million recalled cars and 50 deaths can break congressional gridlock .
After a year of record-breaking recalls and despite a series of congressional hearings revealing critical mistakes by the industry ’ s federal watchdog and what some senators alleged was a criminal cover-up by the nation ’ s largest automaker , reforming the nation ’ s auto safety laws is toward the bottom of this year ’ s congressional to-do list .
Not even personal horror stories — a woman convicted for a role in her boyfriend ’ s death when a General Motors ignition switch defect was at fault , an Air Force lieutenant partially blinded by an exploding airbag , even a recently discovered double defect that could cause an airbag to explode at random and send shrapnel at a driver — have been enough to spur lawmakers in either GOP-controlled chamber of Congress .
“ Are there still some things we can do [ to improve NHTSA ? ] I think there are , ” House Commerce Committee Chairman Fred Upton ( R-Mich. ) said . “ But it ’ s not at the very top of my priority list today . ”
The lack of action stands in sharp contrast to what happened some 15 years ago , the last time Congress overhauled the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration . The Ford-Firestone tire debacle in 2000 was linked to 250 deaths and 3,000 injuries . NHTSA identified the problem in May of that year . By November , tough new laws had been enacted .
It ’ s also not the first time since then that congressional response to a major consumer auto safety crisis has gotten bogged down . In 2010 , sticking accelerator pedals and floor mat problems that caused some models of Toyota to race suddenly led to the recall of nearly 8 million vehicles and forced breathless concern and multiple hearings on Capitol Hill . But comprehensive legislation that would have strengthened NHTSA ’ s ability to police the automobile industry ended up dying in both chambers .
Some pieces of that legislation survived and were included in a major surface transportation law — however those provisions are a ghost of their previous incarnation . The strongest response ended up coming not from Congress , and not from the Transportation Department , but from Department of Justice , which settled a suit against Toyota for $ 1.2 billion — the biggest fine ever levied by the U.S. government against an automaker .
Both then and now , advocates have said Congress needs to enact stronger laws — but overall congressional gridlock has pushed the issue to the sidelines .
Leaders “ didn ’ t see this as something they could get done , ” said Joan Claybrook , NHTSA ’ s first administrator and the former president of Public Citizen , noting opposition from the powerful auto industry would likely bog down progress .
Despite the delay in responding to the latest crisis , advocates insist the political moment hasn ’ t slipped away without action beyond a series of media-friendly hearings that led the evening news .
“ There may not be the TV cameras , there may not be the press of media interest , ” Sen. Richard Blumenthal ( D-Conn. ) , who has emerged as a fierce critic of both the agency and General Motors , told ███ . “ This issue is ever-present to anyone who buys a car . It ’ s still very much on the minds of everyday Americans . ”
Bolstering NHTSA , at least around the edges , is still possible this Congress : both Upton and Senate Commerce Committee Chairman John Thune ( R-S.D . ) said they have ideas about how to improve the agency . A long-term surface transportation bill — which could move as soon as May — would be an ideal vehicle for any changes . But language that can win GOP support is likely to disappoint reform advocates and the administration .
Perhaps the top item on safety advocates ’ wish list is raising or even eliminating the $ 35 million cap on the civil penalties NHTSA can slap automakers with for hiding individual defects . In recent budgets , President Barack Obama has proposed raising the cap from $ 35 million to $ 300 million . Blumenthal and other Democratic senators have proposed eliminating it entirely .
Safety advocates have said eliminating the cap is crucial to making NHTSA a feared regulator . And at least one senator believes automakers essentially dismiss any threat NHTSA might pose as little more than the cost of doing business .
“ It ’ s a sad state of affairs , ” Sen. Claire McCaskill ( D-Mo . ) said during a hearing on the nomination of NHTSA Administrator Mark Rosekind . “ It says a lot about where we are in this country right now and how your agency is viewed . ”
“ If you are not feared and respected , then you can not do a good job policing safety of automobiles in this country . And I don ’ t think NHTSA is either feared or respected at this point , ” McCaskill said .
Even though GM has said implementing its millions of recalls will cost $ 2.5 billion , the $ 35 million NHTSA has handed out in fines amounts to less than one-hundredth of a percent of the the company ’ s 2013 profits of $ 3.8 billion . Upton said he doesn ’ t see a need to raise the cap on fines .
“ I don ’ t know if it was ever going to be big and comprehensive , ” Upton said . He noted that the 2000 NHTSA overhaul bill he authored , called the TREAD Act , “ raised the fines . They ’ ve been paying for it . GM , Toyota paid huge sums as the law requires . ”
Thune said during negotiations in the last Congress , there was a “ consensus spot ” for raising the caps , but didn ’ t get into specifics . “ It ’ s something we ’ ll take a look at . ”
In his 2015 budget , President Barack Obama proposes tripling the agency ’ s budget for defect investigations and increasing the overall budget by 20 percent over the next half-decade , enabling NHTSA to hire more investigators to deal with the 70,000 complaints it receives each year . Thune told reporters he expects that to be a tough sell .
“ Clearly , we want to work with them but it ’ s going to be tough in this budgetary environment with all the constraints we ’ re dealing with to get significant increases in funding for any agency , ” he said .
This , longtime advocates argue , is exactly what the auto industry hopes for .
“ The auto industry always wants to starve the agency to death so it can ’ t operate , ” Claybrook said . She noted NHTSA receives only one percent of the Transportation Department ’ s total funding pot , yet automobile accidents account for 99 percent of transportation deaths and injuries .
Blumenthal said he and Sen. Ed Markey ( D-Mass . ) intend to introduce a number of bills that would improve the agency ’ s transparency and require automakers to put more information into a federal early warning reports system , a critical feature of the TREAD Act . None of Blumenthal and Markey ’ s bills have picked up Republican co-sponsors yet .
“ It ’ s very much an urgent and immediate concern , ” the Connecticut senator said . “ This is a very imminent opportunity as well as an obligation for the Congress to act . Am I disappointed ? Yes , but I also understand that sometimes legislation takes time . ”
One piece of legislation is likely to move : A bill by Thune and Commerce Committee ranking member Bill Nelson ( D-Fla. ) intended to incentivize whistleblowers by offering them one-third of any fines NHTSA collects that top $ 1 million . But the agency said gathering more tips isn ’ t really the problem .
“ We need the resources , the people and the dollars to follow up on those leads , ” NHTSA deputy administrator David Friedman , then the agency ’ s top official , said at the November hearing where Thune and Nelson first proposed the bill .
At one point last year , stronger action looked likely . Senators in both parties were furious with GM officials , including CEO Mary Barra , over the recall scandal . The scandal burst into public consciousness in late January , when GM ordered 2.1 million cars recalled due to an ignition switch defect that could lead to cars suddenly stopping while airbags fail to deploy . The defect has since been linked to more than 50 deaths . Some GM employees knew about the problem more than a decade earlier , and congressional investigators uncovered repeated missed opportunities for NHTSA to diagnose the problem .
The resulting uproar sparked what would become a record year for recalls , as the other members of the Big Three as well as foreign automakers began ordering recalls en masse to prevent scandals of their own . The record for recalls in a single year was broken in October . The final tally of 60 million was double the previous modern high .
With the recalls came congressional condemnation . McCaskill , then the chair of the Senate Commerce subcommitee for consumer protection , accused NHTSA of being “ more interested in singing ‘ Kumbaya ’ with the manufacturers than being a cop on the beat ” and GM had a “ culture of cover-up. ” Sen. Kelly Ayotte ( R-N.H. ) accused GM of engaging in “ criminal deception . ”
But that anger hasn ’ t translated into action . McCaskill , who no longer chairs the subcommittee , said she didn ’ t plan to reintroduce a multi-year NHTSA reauthorization she put out last October . She also said she didn ’ t know when the committee would look at the auto safety regulator .
“ All we ’ ve been talking about is net neutrality , ” she said .
NHTSA is evaluating itself , however . A spokesman said a “ due diligence ” report on its failure to identify the ignition switch problem earlier , ordered up by Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx , would be out in “ the coming weeks. ” The agency is also working on a workforce assessment to help it better align staffing with new technologies . The DOT ’ s inspector general and the Government Accountability Office are working on their own reports .
And the agency ’ s new head , former National Transportation Safety Board member Mark Rosekind , has said he plans on cracking down on automakers and forcing even more recalls in 2015 .
“ I would expect that we ’ ll probably actually see an increase in recalls , ” he told reporters at a roundtable shortly after his confirmation . “ This was the year of the recall right ? Put your seat belt on , folks . ”

“There may not be the TV cameras, there may not be the press of media interest,” Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.), who has emerged as a fierce critic of both the agency and General Motors, told POLITICO. “This issue is ever-present to anyone who buys a car. It’s still very much on the minds of everyday Americans.”

Bolstering NHTSA, at least around the edges, is still possible this Congress: both Upton and Senate Commerce Committee Chairman John Thune (R-S.D.) said they have ideas about how to improve the agency. A long-term surface transportation bill — which could move as soon as May — would be an ideal vehicle for any changes. But language that can win GOP support is likely to disappoint reform advocates and the administration.

Safety advocates have said eliminating the cap is crucial to making NHTSA a feared regulator. And at least one senator believes automakers essentially dismiss any threat NHTSA might pose as little more than the cost of doing business.

“It’s a sad state of affairs,” Sen. Claire McCaskill (D-Mo.) said during a hearing on the nomination of NHTSA Administrator Mark Rosekind. “It says a lot about where we are in this country right now and how your agency is viewed.”

“If you are not feared and respected, then you cannot do a good job policing safety of automobiles in this country. And I don’t think NHTSA is either feared or respected at this point,” McCaskill said.

Even though GM has said implementing its millions of recalls will cost $2.5 billion, the $35 million NHTSA has handed out in fines amounts to less than one-hundredth of a percent of the the company’s 2013 profits of $3.8 billion. Upton said he doesn’t see a need to raise the cap on fines.

“I don’t know if it was ever going to be big and comprehensive,” Upton said. He noted that the 2000 NHTSA overhaul bill he authored, called the TREAD Act, “raised the fines. They’ve been paying for it. GM, Toyota paid huge sums as the law requires.”

Thune said during negotiations in the last Congress, there was a “consensus spot” for raising the caps, but didn’t get into specifics. “It’s something we’ll take a look at.”

“The auto industry always wants to starve the agency to death so it can’t operate,” Claybrook said. She noted NHTSA receives only one percent of the Transportation Department’s total funding pot, yet automobile accidents account for 99 percent of transportation deaths and injuries.

Blumenthal said he and Sen. Ed Markey (D-Mass.) intend to introduce a number of bills that would improve the agency’s transparency and require automakers to put more information into a federal early warning reports system, a critical feature of the TREAD Act. None of Blumenthal and Markey’s bills have picked up Republican co-sponsors yet.

“It’s very much an urgent and immediate concern,” the Connecticut senator said. “This is a very imminent opportunity as well as an obligation for the Congress to act. Am I disappointed? Yes, but I also understand that sometimes legislation takes time.”

One piece of legislation is likely to move: A bill by Thune and Commerce Committee ranking member Bill Nelson (D-Fla.) intended to incentivize whistleblowers by offering them one-third of any fines NHTSA collects that top $1 million. But the agency said gathering more tips isn’t really the problem.

“We need the resources, the people and the dollars to follow up on those leads,” NHTSA deputy administrator David Friedman, then the agency’s top official, said at the November hearing where Thune and Nelson first proposed the bill.

At one point last year, stronger action looked likely. Senators in both parties were furious with GM officials, including CEO Mary Barra, over the recall scandal. The scandal burst into public consciousness in late January, when GM ordered 2.1 million cars recalled due to an ignition switch defect that could lead to cars suddenly stopping while airbags fail to deploy. The defect has since been linked to more than 50 deaths. Some GM employees knew about the problem more than a decade earlier, and congressional investigators uncovered repeated missed opportunities for NHTSA to diagnose the problem.

The resulting uproar sparked what would become a record year for recalls, as the other members of the Big Three as well as foreign automakers began ordering recalls en masse to prevent scandals of their own. The record for recalls in a single year was broken in October. The final tally of 60 million was double the previous modern high.

With the recalls came congressional condemnation. McCaskill, then the chair of the Senate Commerce subcommitee for consumer protection, accused NHTSA of being “more interested in singing ‘Kumbaya’ with the manufacturers than being a cop on the beat” and GM had a “culture of cover-up.” Sen. Kelly Ayotte (R-N.H.) accused GM of engaging in “criminal deception.”

But that anger hasn’t translated into action. McCaskill, who no longer chairs the subcommittee, said she didn’t plan to reintroduce a multi-year NHTSA reauthorization she put out last October. She also said she didn’t know when the committee would look at the auto safety regulator.

“All we’ve been talking about is net neutrality,” she said.

NHTSA is evaluating itself, however. A spokesman said a “due diligence” report on its failure to identify the ignition switch problem earlier, ordered up by Transportation Secretary Anthony Foxx, would be out in “the coming weeks.” The agency is also working on a workforce assessment to help it better align staffing with new technologies. The DOT’s inspector general and the Government Accountability Office are working on their own reports.

And the agency’s new head, former National Transportation Safety Board member Mark Rosekind, has said he plans on cracking down on automakers and forcing even more recalls in 2015.

“I would expect that we’ll probably actually see an increase in recalls,” he told reporters at a roundtable shortly after his confirmation. “This was the year of the recall right? Put your seat belt on, folks.”
